campaign.story:
CORVID-19: A RavenCon Anthology
2020 has been a challenging year for all of us. No one expected the world to come to a grinding halt. No one expected stores to run out of toilet paper, or the Tiger King to be a thing on Netflix, but here we are.
After planning, prepping, and purchasing all of the supplies for our 2020 event, the pandemic hit. Everything started shutting down. Conventions and all in-person events were cancelled.  RavenCon led the way, putting our guests' safety above all else, and we were one of the first to cancel—3 weeks before the convention. We had spent eleven months purchasing supplies for an event that wasn’t going to happen. 
As a fan-run convention, we pride ourselves in being there for emerging artists, writers, and vendors. We may be small, but our heart is mighty.
We know the community is vital to many of you. Conventions are a way to meet with your friends, to make new friends and new connections. To boldly go where you haven't been before, and to come together as a family. We don't want this to end, but 2020 was certainly bent on it. This is where we need your help.
Michael Pederson had an idea (a lot of RavenCon stories start with this sentence, by the way).  Why not make something everyone can enjoy? We are all home much more often now; what's better than reading a good book? So, we reached out to our past guests, and began collecting our "tribute" to 2020: CORVID-19, an anthology. Yes, you read that right. CORVID-19. An anthology themed around the corvidae family of birds—ravens, crows, bluejays, magpies, etc.
Our generous and talented author friends have donated their stories, now we need your help to get this published. You can also support the convention so we can thrive for years to come. 
We have something for everyone! You can choose to be a major or minor character in a book! Maybe you want to be a Red Shirt and get killed off? We have that too. Want stickers? We have that. Want help with the story you're writing? We got you! Mad for music? We hear you. Take a look at the list of pledge levels and for ways to help support us. 
We couldn't run RavenCon without you. We thank you for everything you have helped us with over the last 15 years, and we don't want this pandemic to take that away. 
Thank you for sharing our project, for supporting us, and we look forward to seeing you when we can be face to face again. 
What exactly are the nineteen corvid-filled stories in this 210-page volume of awesomeness? Just look at what we’ve got…
“Windows to the Soul” by Danielle Ackley-McPhail
“Raven’s Sacrifice” by Heather Ewings
“The Cruelest Team Will Win” by Mike Allen
“Jenny” by Debbie Manber Kupfer
“Daughter of the Birds” by Maya Preisler
“Kvetina and the Crows” by Rhys Schrock
“Corvus Monitus” by Cass Morris
“If the Moon is Real” by Samantha Bryant
“Life in a Moment” by James Maxey
“Crows’ Feet” by Diana Bastine
“A Warning of Crows” by Jennifer R. Povey
“Wet Birds” by Elizabeth Massie
“Heart Truth” by Jenna Hamrick
“Table for One” by Joan Wendland
“Dominion” by Margaret Karmazin
“The Gore-Crow” by Meryl Yourish
“The Song of the Raven” by Toi Thomas
“Fledging” by Kathryn Sullivan
“Feather Fall” by Kara Dennison
Wondering what other things we have up our sleeves? We are already at work on Volume 2. What’s Volume 2? Well that’s CORVID-19: The Second Wave. Once we reach our first stretch goal of $4000, everyone who is getting the book will get a digital copy of The Second Wave. 
My feathers are a flutter just thinking about this! Or maybe that’s just a bad hamberder.)

*Update! Our second stretch goal of $4500 wil get everyone who supported us at the $10 or more level will also be getting a limited-edition bookmark and button made exclusively for this kickstarter! 
CORVID-19 Button
*Update! When we reach $5000 everyone who receives the trade paperback of CORVID-19 (volume 1) will also receive the trade paperback for volume 2 CORVID-19: The Second Wave.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Things happen. Carole Baskin’s husband goes missing. People hoard toilet paper and hot dogs. Sit back, have a cup of cofveve, and know that while we know nothing is normal right now, we will be open with you about everything. 

Shipping can be a little slower at the moment, but we will keep you abreast of when things ship out. 

Once the Kickstarter ends, we can begin the printing process and ship immediately thereafter for those who have purchased the book. 

For any author-related levels: well, this takes time. Characters have to live out their scenes from the writer’s head to the paper, and writing and editing takes time. Please be patient with your author buddy.

For those who selected any writing-critiques: this one is a two way street. We will connect you, but you must also give your proofreader time to read over, evaluate, and give feed back. We will make sure you have a way to connect with them that is comfortable for both of you.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content: Hey everyone! We are just days away now from having the publisher’s copy of the book in our hands! We sent it off and it should be arriving any time now. WOOT! As long as this looks good and we don’t see any printing errors, then we will run the full processing, and get your orders out!! I can’t WAIT to see it! 😃 Ahhh the smell of fresh book.... soon!! So soon!!!

Hello everyone!! We are near complete with book one, but because everyone who backed a level has a name going in the anthology, we can’t complete it until we hear back from everyone.
I’ve sent out a message to anyone that I needed more information from- mostly your name for the anthology, and what email or street address to send your rewards to. (So, if you didn’t get an email from me or you filled your survey out, you’re good.)

updates.update_userinfo: Update! Did we hear back from you?
updates.update_content:
Hi everyone!
It’s been a week of almost no power out here in the country. Storms came through and knocked out power, which takes out our heat, water, WiFi... everything. We are back up and running. My thoughts are with everyone in Texas, and I am hoping things get better out there. Living in a cold house is no fun.

Whew! We did it! We are excited, grateful and humbled at the outpouring of support for this project and our convention community. We wouldn’t be here if it weren’t for you, and we thank you for being here for us. What happens now?
Over the next week we will need a little more information from you, this so that I can make sure to get your backer package out. You’ll receive a survey, so keep your eyes peeled.

Corvid-19: The Second Wave is coming together nicely! We’ve got some great stories from the following authors:
Samantha Bryant
Jude-Marie Green
Cheralyn Lambeth

W00T! We’ve unlocked the next stretch goal- $5000! That means if you have backed us with a reward that gets the paperback of the first book CORVID-19: A RavenCon Anthology, you will ALSO be getting the second book: CORVID-19: The Second Wave. Thanks everyone! It’s our last week before this all ends. We still have time for you to back us and choose to be killed off in a story, or become a minor or major character in a story, get some new music, or join an RPG Podcast! And, of course- there’s still time to get the book and help get us to our last goal- $7,000! Thanks for having our back!

Update! Update! We’ve done amazing so far, and are hard at work editing and getting packages together for our backers! We are so close to making our Big Goal of $7,000! Once we hit this goal we’ll reward one of our Backers with the position of Fan Guest of Honor for the next RavenCon (currently scheduled for April 29-May 1, 2022). The Fan GOH will receive a $200 travel stipend, a hotel room for Friday AND Saturday night, two badges, and will be a panelist on three or more panels during the convention. The Fan GOH will also have access to the Green Room. The winner will be randomly chosen from our Backers (if the winner, for whatever reason, can’t make it to the convention we’ll redraw for another winner). This means that ALL of our backers, big or small will all be eligible to be entered into the drawing!

You’ve unlocked the second stretch goal! Persons who are supporting the project at the $10 or more level will be receiving a limited edition bookmark and button!
More updates & photos coming at the end of the week!

campaign.story:
Thrilling Adventure Yarns 2021
Apparently, I was far from alone in my adoration of the old pulp magazines, which were plentiful and influential a century ago. Last year, to honor those halcyon days, I conceived of Thrilling Adventure Yarns and invited a ton of friends, old and new, to join me in this celebration.
I then turned to you, the discerning reader, for support. I was stunned and gratified to not only meet my objective but far, far exceed it. We earned 248% of the goal, which allowed me to bring our readers a number of attractive and exciting options I would not have been able to provide otherwise.
We had fun producing the book, and our reviews and personal comments were almost all laudatory. The common question was, “When is the next book?” The answer is February. 
The second common question was, "When is the next Thrilling Adventures Kickstarter?"
The answer is: NOW!
As part of Crazy 8 Press’ 10th-anniversary celebration, we will release a second volume, once more packed with all genres of pulp goodness, with several returning authors along with new ones. Several characters from our first volume will be making second appearances here, including Cannon Belle! Other Crazy 8 characters will also be appearing here, including a tale from the Crimson Keep and Angela Hardwicke, private detective!
Joining me on this journey will be C8’s Aaron Rosenberg, Michael Jan Friedman, Glenn Hauman, Mary Fan, Paul Kupperberg, and Russ Colchamiro.
Returning will be David Mack, Paige Daniels, Will Murray, and Karissa Laurel.
New to this volume will be William Leisner, Danielle Ackley McPhail, Dayton Ward & Kevin Dilmore, Greg Cox, Heather E. Hutsell, Kelli Fitzpatrick, Michael A. Burstein, Richard White, Scott Pearson, and Sherri Cook Woosley.
Another Historic Coup!
We have also secured the rights to a true relic of the glory days of the pulps: A previously unpublished detective tale by none other than Lester Dent, the creator of Doc Savage! This is a milestone in the history of the pulp magazines, available only to the backers of this campaign.
We're really excited about Thrilling Adventure Yarns—in part, at least, because of this great cover by the inestimable artist Gary Carbon. Feast your eyes on this image and you can see for yourself that the days of yore will be treated with deep affection.
Our Goal!
This isn't the kind of publishing project in which the publisher takes the lion's share of the profits and doles out the scraps to those who've done all the work. All funds that remain after the expenses of acquiring the Lester Dent story, commissioning the cover, designing the book, funding a print run, and sending out rewards to our backers will be divvied up by our editor and our writers in equal amounts. If we reach our goal of at least $6000, we'll be able to accomplish all that.
But it's our hope to earn enough to add some other authors as well, and maybe, just maybe, to reach a stretch goal that will enable us to add interior illustrations.
It all comes down to you.
A la Carte!
This handy-dandy a la carte menu enables you to customize your reward package—to receive all the things you want and none of the things you don't. Just take any existing package of $25 and up, and add to it the dollar amount associated with any item or items on the following list. Then send us a message letting us know what additional reward or rewards you've qualified for. (International backers, there will be some additional postage; if you're interested in an add-on, shoot us a message and we'll figure it out.)
Get listed as a patron on the acknowledgments page  $10.
Receive a one-time mention as a character, street, company, etc.  $35.
E-book package #1 $20.
E-book package #2 $20.
E-book package #3 $20.
Package #1 includes Lost Days by Michael Jan Friedman, Cats Triumphant by Jody Lynn Nye, The Wild Adventures of Sherlock Holmes by Will Murray, Harbinger of Darkness by Richard C. White, and Baba Ali and the Clockwork Djinn by Day Al-Mohamed and Danielle Ackley-Mcphail.
Package #2 includes Transcendence and The Halfling's Court by Danielle Ackley McPhail, Flynn Nightsider and the Edge of Evil, by Mary Fan, Altered States of the Union, edited by Glenn Hauman, In the Services of the Guild by Tina Closser, and "Midnight Rider" by David Mack.
Package #3 includes In My Shorts by Paul Kupperberg, Crackle and Fire by Russ Colchamiro, One Haunted Summer by Aaron Rosenberg, Eternal Wanderings by Danielle Ackley-McPhail, and "Our Possible Pasts" by David Mack
For $25 more, you can upgrade your trade paperback to a hardcover edition (after the option is unlocked, of course).
Stretch Goals!
UNLOCKED! At $7000 we unlock "the hardcover option," allowing any backer whose reward includes a paperback copy to upgrade to a handsome hardback version of Thrilling Adventure Yarns 2021 (see A La Carte menu above).
UNLOCKED! At $7250, I will be able to include a story from Stuart Moore, an editor/writer with credits from St. Martin's Press, Vertigo Comics, Marvel Comics, and currently Ahoy! Comics. His previous prose works include collaborations with Stan Lee and several Marvel novels.
At $7500, I will be able to include a story from veteran comics writer Ron Marz, whose credits span from Witchblade to Green Lantern, from DC vs. Marvel to Batman/Aliens. His work speaks for itself and here he'll be making a rare prose appearance.
At $7750, I will be able to include a story from Jody Lynn Nye, the prolific author of over 40 books and more than 120 short stories, spanning genres. 
$8000, I will be able to include a story from the possibly even more prolific Jonathan Maberry, he of V-Wars and Joe Ledger fame. The multiple Bram Stoker Award-winning author continues to write and edit across genres.
At $8500 we will upgrade those receiving one signature to three signatures from our illustrious cadre of authors. (See Risks and Challenges for options.)
At $9000 we can send everyone a digital art set of images, suitable for your digital wallpaper.
At $10,000, it will allow me to hire a cadre of talented artists to render a black and white illustration for each and every story in the collection. Last time, we had work from Mark Wheatley, Peter Krause, Jerry Ordway, Karl Kesel, and Tom Mandrake. We're already lining up several new names should we reach this level!
At $10,500 we will up our guarantee of three autographs per print edition to five autographs. (See Risks and Challenges for options.).
At $12,000 we will have a Kickstarter-exclusive cover from Richard Pace, who has illustrated for Vertigo and Marvel and has also co-written Dale Keown’s Pitt and Batman: The Doom That Came to Gotham and is the co-creator, with Mark Russell, of the hit indie AHOY Comics series Second Coming. Only backers will receive this exclusive edition in softcover and/or hardcover.
We'll be announcing other stretch goals as our campaign develops. We don't want to give away all our secrets!

The manuscript is complete, and more than half of it is already edited. And as someone who has edited and published books for DC Comics and Marvel, this is hardly my first go-around as a talent wrangler.

Covid-19 may make gathering writers together complicated so the alternative to gathering multiple signatures would be creating an exclusive bookplate that the requisite number of authors would sign, which would be included with your physical copy of the book.

Of course, there are always unforeseen obstacles. But barring something horrific, we will deliver what we've promised well within the time parameters in which we've promised it.

updates.update_content: I just returned from the post office and can say with confidence that every book has now been personally packed and labeled by yours truly. The Post Office grumbled at the volume but all domestic and international copies are now in their hands.

All backers who wanted digital rewards, including the book, wallpapers, and other goodies in the various tiers, should check their messages. I just sent out the links to the various files.
As I said there, I remain incredibly proud of how well the book turned out and i am very happy ot be finally sharing it with you.
For print backers, the hardcovers are due later today and they will all be autographed over the next few weeks then packed and shipped. Your continued patience is appreciated.

I would love to tell you that the book is done and ready to be printed, and we're right on schedule.
However, for the first time in my career as a book editor, I fear to say we're slipping behind schedule. This is directly attributable to one final story taking longer than expected to arrive. Its illustration is due tonight, completing the elements.

Last time, I thought I had a killer lineup of artists to illustrate the stories but I think our roster this time around is a true Murderer's Row. With 27 stories to bring to life, I needed a larger assortment of talent and when the call went out, I got quite the response.
Here is our collection of creators:
June Brigman (Power Pack, Mary Worth), Kerry Callen (Halo and Sprocket), Gary Carbon (), Mike Collins (), Daerick Gross (), Matt Haley ( ), Karl Kesel (), Peter Krause ( ), Mike Manley (), Luke McDonnell (), Ron Randall (), Bart Sears ( League Europe, ), Daniele Sera (), Mark Wheatley (), and Jeff Weigel ().

As promised, the hardcover option has now been unlocked. Anyone desiring this, can add $25 to their pledge and note you want the hardcover.
Next up,  I will be able to include a story from Stuart Moore, an editor/writer with credits from St. Martin's Press, Vertigo Comics, Marvel Comics, and currently Ahoy! Comics. His previous prose works include collaborations with Stan Lee and several Marvel novels. We're just $250 from this one.

Submission Guidelines:
We funded! Yay! Now let's reach for those stretch goals! (Free ebooks? Additional stories in the anthos? Perhaps even a FOURTH anthology? Why not?) In the meantime, here's the link to the submission guidelines for the writers out there:   https://www.patreon.com/posts/40888189 . If you have a story idea that fits one of the three themes described below, write it up, revise it, polish it, and then send it in for consideration! You may end up in one of these anthologies!
This project will fund THREE science fiction and fantasy anthologies, titled THE MODERN DEITY'S GUIDE TO SURVIVING HUMANITY, DERELICT, and WHEN WORLDS COLLIDE, containing approximately 14 all-original (no reprint) short stories each from established SF&F authors in the field and new voices found through an open call. The books will be edited by Patricia Bray & Joshua Palmatier (THE MODERN DEITY'S GUIDE TO SURVIVING HUMANITY), David B. Coe & Joshua Palmatier (DERELICT), and S.C. Butler & Joshua Palmatier (WHEN WORLDS COLLIDE).
THE MODERN DEITY'S GUIDE TO SURVIVING HUMANITY:
In this follow-up to THE MODERN FAE'S GUIDE TO SURVIVING HUMANITY, we switch our attention to how the deities of old have managed to fit themselves into today's modern world! Is Narcissus an Instagram influencer? Is Coyote playing the stock market? Does Ra own a solar panel company? Was Dr. Ruth really Venus? How have the gods and goddesses managed to survive alongside cell phones and computers and social media influencers? We invite authors to explore how the immortals have changed with the times.
Edited by Patricia Bray & Joshua Palmatier, THE MODERN DEITY'S GUIDE TO SURVIVING HUMANITY will contain approximately fourteen stories with an average length of 6,000 words each.  Anchor authors (and the gods they may use) include:
Alma Alexander (Freyja: Nordic),
David Farland (Woden/Odin: German),
Tanya Huff (Hera: Greek),
Juliet E. McKenna (Nemesis/Themis: Greek),
Phyllis Irene Radford (Anshar/Tiamet: Babylonian),
Laura Resnick (assorted),
Kari Sperring (Cigfa, Goewin, Gwydion: Welsh),
Jean Marie Ward (Dionysus: Greek), and
Edward Willett (Ninkasi: Sumerian)
DERELICT:
No one can resist the mystery of the abandoned ship--whether it's the ghost ship found afloat at sea in the Bermuda Triangle or the spaceship drifting in the depths of space a la the movie Alien. What happened to the crew? What horror forced them to abandon their vessel and flee…or are they still on board, trapped or even all dead? In this anthology, we want authors to explore all of the possibilities when one runs across…a DERELICT.
Edited by David B. Coe & Joshua Palmatier, DERELICT will contain approximately fourteen stories with an average length of 6,000 words each. Anchor authors include:
Jacey Bedford,
Alex Bledsoe,
Gerald Brandt,
Julie E. Czerneda,
Kate Elliott,
John G. Hemry/Jack Campbell,
D.B. Jackson,
Gini Koch,
Sharon Lee & Steve Miller, and
Kristine Smith
WHEN WORLDS COLLIDE:
Throughout history, different cultures have collided in different ways, whether it be the peaceful contact between Rome and Han China in the second century that established the Silk Road, or the more violent interactions between Europe and the Americas thirteen hundred years later. Such first contact stories have long been a staple of speculative fiction. The stories featured in WHEN WORLDS COLLIDE will continue this long tradition as the authors explore the myriad ways in which two cultures—alien or fae, machine or human—can clash. Will the colliding societies manage to peacefully coexist after they finally meet? Or will they embark instead on a path of mutual self-destruction? Find out—WHEN WORLDS COLLIDE.
Edited by S.C. Butler & Joshua Palmatier, WHEN WORLDS COLLIDE will contain approximately fourteen stories with an average length of 6,000 words each.  Anchor authors include:
S.C. Butler,
Esther Friesner,
Auston Habershaw,
Steven Harper,
Nancy Holzner,
Howard Andrew Jones,
Stephen Leigh,
Violette Malan, and
Alan Smale
Backers of this project will essentially be generating the base funds needed to produce these three anthologies—including payment for the contributing authors, payment for the cover artist, production costs for producing the anthology, etc. Because of this, the reward levels for the anthologies have been set to more closely resemble the cost of the final product when it goes on sale to the general public. In essence, backers of the project are simply “preordering” the anthologies, although there will be a special mass market Kickstarter edition produced for backers who help fund the project at the paperback level. This special edition will have a limited print run to cover the orders made by the backers and will not be printed again after the Kickstarter print run. After that, there will be a trade paperback edition issued to the general public that will have an unlimited print run.
So get in on the Kickstarter now and get the special mass market Kickstarter edition!

The following is a Reward Level Rundown for most of the rewards where the backer will get all three of the three anthologies in either ebook or limited-edition mass market paperback format. There are a few reward levels not listed, such as those where the backer gets only one or two of the anthologies in either format, as well as a few special reward levels where the backer will get ALL of the currently-available backlist from Zombies Need Brains in either ebook or limited-edition mass market paperback--those three levels are ZNB Ebook Zombie, ZNB Kickstarter Zombie, and ZNB Ebook Kickstarter Zombie.
If the Kickstarter is funded, the intention is to have all stories handed in by the end of December 2020. We expect the editing and revision process to be finished by the end of February 2021 and the ebook and physical books to be designed, produced, and ready for release by the end of August 2021. Funding will cover the costs of producing the ebook in all standard formats (MOBI, Epub, PDF), producing mass market paperback versions of the anthology for the backers, cover art commission, payment of the editors, advances for the authors (at a minimum of 8 cents per word), and advertising and promotional expenses. Funding above the minimum would be used to increase the advances of the authors, allow for higher production values for the ebooks and books, increase the number of stories in the anthology, and increased advertising.
Stretch goals would include an increase in pay for the authors, adding additional story slots to the books, etc. We will be adding more stretch goals as those at the lower levels are achieved. Here are the stretch goals so far:

Stretch Goal: At $22,000, all backers pledged at $7 or more will receive Jean Marie Ward's ebook "Four For More" (PDF only) AND Edward Willett's ebook "Paths to the Stars."

Stretch Goal: At $26,000, all backers pledged at $7 or more will receive the ebook "When Josie Comes Home" by A.E. Stanton (aka Gini Koch), the first installment of THE NEW WEST series.
Stretch Goal:  At $27,000, all backers pledged at $7 or more will receive the ebook "An Alewife in Kish" by Benjamin Tate (aka Joshua Palmatier).
Stretch Goal: At $28,000, all backers pledged at $7 or more will receive Jean Marie Ward's ebook "With Nine You Get Vanyr" (PDF only) AND Edward Willett's ebook "From the Street to the Stars."
Stretch Goal: At $29,000, every backer pledged at $7 or more will receive the ebook "Three Card Monte" by Gini Koch, the second installment of THE MARTIAN ALLIANCE CHRONICLES series.
Stretch Goal: At $30,000, we will add an additional story to each anthology using the submissions from the open call, so each anthology will feature 15 stories minimum.
Stretch Goal: At $32,500, every backer pledging $7 or more will receive the ebook "Deacon's Ark" by A.E. Stanton (aka Gini Koch), the second installment of THE NEW WEST series.

Stretch Goal: A FOURTH ANTHOLOGY!:  At $40,000, Zombies Need Brains LLC will produce a FOURTH themed anthology, theme to be determined if we reach this stretch goal.  It will be edited by Joshua Palmatier.  Details about how to add the ebook or paperback version of this anthology to your reward level will be announced once we reach this stretch goal.

Here’s a brief introduction to the editors of the anthologies:
Patricia Bray: Patricia Bray is the author of a dozen novels, including Devlin’s Luck, which won the 2003 Compton Crook Award for the best first novel in the field of science fiction or fantasy. A multi-genre author whose career spans both epic fantasy and Regency romance, her books have been translated into Russian, German, Portuguese and Hebrew. Patricia lives in a New England college town, where she combines her writing with a full-time career as a Systems Analyst, ensuring that she is never more than a few feet away from a keyboard. Find her online at www.patriciabray.com.
S.C. Butler: S. C. Butler is a writer living in New Hampshire with his wife and son. He is the author of the "Stoneways" trilogy: Reiffen’s Choice, Queen Ferris, and The Magicians’ Daughter, published by Tor Books; and a contributor of short stories to several anthologies and magazines. Submerged was his debut as an editor.
David B. Coe: David B. Coe: David B. Coe/D.B. Jackson is the author of two dozen novels and as many short stories.  As D.B. Jackson (http://www.DBJackson-Author.com), he is the author of The Islevale Cycle (TIME’S CHILDREN, TIME’S DEMON, TIME’S ASSASSIN) a time travel/epic fantasy series. He also writes the Thieftaker Chronicles, a series set in pre-Revolutionary Boston that combines elements of urban fantasy, mystery, and historical fiction. Under his own name (http://www.DavidBCoe.com) he has written the Crawford Award-winning LonTobyn Chronicle, the critically acclaimed Winds of the Forelands quintet and Blood of the Southlands trilogy, the novelization Ridley Scott’s, ROBIN HOOD, and a contemporary urban fantasy series, the Case Files of Justis Fearsson. He is the co-author of How To Write Magical Words: A Writer’s Companion. David has a Ph.D. in U.S. history from Stanford University. His books have been translated into a dozen languages.
Joshua Palmatier: A professor of mathematics at SUNY Oneonta, Joshua Palmatier has published nine novels—the “Throne of Amenkor” series (The Skewed Throne, The Cracked Throne, The Vacant Throne) with DAW, the “Well of Sorrows” series (Well of Sorrows, Leaves of Flame, Breath of Heaven) with Baen and Zombies Need Brains, and the "Ley" series (Shattering the Ley, Threading the Needle, Reaping the Aurora) with DAW. He is currently at work on the start of a new series. He has also published numerous short stories—“Mastihooba” in Close Encounters of the Urban Kind and “Tears of Blood” in Beauty Has Her Way (both edited by Jennifer Brozek), “The River” in River (edited by Alma Alexander), and "Daughter of the Sands" in Apollo's Daughters (edited by Brian Young). Find out more at www.joshuapalmatier.com and www.zombiesneedbrains.com.
Zombies Need Brains LLC is a small press owned and operated by Joshua Palmatier that focuses on producing professional quality science fiction and fantasy themed anthologies initially funded by Kickstarters. Having successfully published ten anthologies in the last five years, ZNB is currently expanding its anthology production, with the intent to eventually publish stand-alone books once the press has gained its footing. Check out the webpage at www.zombiesneedbrains.comand the online store at https://squareup.com/market/zombies-need-brains-llc. Signup for our newsletter at http://eepurl.com/dv3TLv.  You can also find Zombies Need Brains on Facebook (https://www.facebook.com/zombiesneedbrainsllc/) and Twitter (@ZNBLLC).
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
As with any production of a book, the timeline for delivery of the book may change due to unexpected delays in the editing process or the production process (such as a delay in printing at the press, etc). Every effort will be made to have the books ready for release and in backers’ hands by August 2021. Also, there is always a slight chance that life and circumstances will force a confirmed anchor author to drop out of the anthology. In the unlikely event that an author cannot deliver a story for whatever reason, their slot would be filled with an author from the slush pile. Since everyone involved—both anchor authors and editors—are professionals in the field already, there is no real expectation that there will be a delay or that the confirmed authors will not deliver, but it does happen on occasion.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Quick update: Still waiting on the printer for the Kickstarter editions of DERELICT, WHEN WORLDS COLLIDE, and THE MODERN DEITY'S GUIDE TO SURVIVING HUMANITY. Once I have them in hand, I'll immediately start shipping them out and will send the ebooks to all of you cool backers. Again, the printer said they'd be ready by the end of June, so it's getting close. Fingers crossed there wasn't some kind of "delay" in the printing process.
In the meantime, Zombies Need Brains is moving forward and planning for the NEXT Kickstarter! We'll be running it starting sometime in August, as usual, with Justin Adams doing the cover art for all three of the new themes. He's already got one done--the one we'll use as the Kickstarter artwork. I've listed the themes, editors, and anchor authors we currently have lined up below, followed by the main artwork we'll be using. (The anthology the art is for should be obvious.) I hope this gets you excited for what's coming next and that I'll see you all as backers when the time comes! And for you writers, we'll be doing an open call for submissions for all three of these themes, so get those backbrains burning and come up with a stunning idea, write it up, revise it, and send it on in if we fund!

At this point, you should have gotten two Dropbox Transfer emails--one for Early Backer Incentives (if you backed the Kickstarter before we hit $17.5K) and one for Stretch Goals (everyone). If you didn't, check your spam folders. This transfer SHOULD NOT REQUIRE YOU TO JOIN DROPBOX! It's something relatively new for Dropbox; it is not a "share" (which does require you have a Dropbox account).
Take note: some backers have found that the files download automatically, without you needing to click on a download button. So if you're not seeing a download button to click, check to see if it's downloaded itself automatically.

updates.update_userinfo: Early Backer Incentives and Stretch Goals
updates.update_content: Just FYI, I will be sending out the Early Backer Incentives and Stretch Goals here shortly. All of these are ebooks that were donated by anchor authors. I will be delivering them via a Dropbox Transfer, which is supposed to be a method of delivery that does NOT require you to have a Dropbox account. It should provide you with a link so that you can download the files. Some computers may say that the link is suspicious and ask you to verify the link. I'm sending this update as a way for you to know that the link is valid.

I've had a request for an update, so here it is! At this stage, the anthologies have been sent to the printer so it's all in the hands of the printer's schedule. I've been told an estimate on delivery of the books to me is the end of June, which is later than usual. (Normally I get them at the end of May or beginning of June.) Once I have them, I'll start sending them out immediately. I'll send links to the ebooks at about the same time. Right now, I'm working on designing the interiors of the trade paperbacks and the covers for the trade paperbacks.

updates.update_userinfo: Update! And ToCs and Back Cover Copies!
updates.update_content: Time for an update! We've gotten all the way up to page proofs in the publishing process so far! What that means is that we're almost ready to send things off to the printer. The next few weeks will involve the authors checking over their page proofs to make certain there aren't any additional changes they want to make to their stories and also a hunt for typos. We've gone through the stories probably ten times already, but somehow the typos still end up making it into the final print book. Trust me, we're trying to catch them all. Once they're done with the page proofs, the interior is ready to send to the printer. I'll be working on the cover art in the meantime, so that hopefully we'll be able to hand the anthologies off to the printer sometime in April. Finger crossed we get them back by June. Once I hand them over, it's more or less out of our hands and up to the printer's schedule.

So I've got cover art to reveal for the WHEN WORLDS COLLIDE and DERELICT anthologies! Again, this cover art is by Justin Adams of Varia Studios. You can get prints of the art at the Zombies Need Brains online store for $10 each, wallpapers are also available at $2 each (3 sizes), and of course you can preorder the Kickstarter edition and the ebooks for any of the three new anthologies as well.

An update!

First, if you had any add-on ebooks for Zombies Need Brains anthologies that are already available (and you've filled out your survey already), I've sent out transfer links to the email address you provided so you can download them. You have one week to download them before the link expires! So download them NOW, rather than later. If you miss the window, not a problem, I can send the transfer link again, but I'd really appreciate it if you do it now instead of later.

I've just finished sending out all of the surveys for the reward levels. You should find an email in your Kickstarter email inbox (check the spam folders and such if you don't see it soon). If you need to provide an address, I've set it up so that you can change your address at any time. Remember, the three new anthologies won't go out until summer next year, so these surveys are more for those that got add-ons or special rewards that need to be shipped now rather than later (for holiday gifts or whatever). If you don't need your extra items now or you only got the new anthologies, no need to rush on the survey.

So, Kickstarter is running the numbers, since this project was successful. Check your email in case they had an issue running your credit card. I'd hate for someone to miss out because of a mixed-up expiration date or something. They send out a couple messages, but if you haven't fixed the problem by a certain date, your pledge gets dropped.
Also wanted to remind everyone that if you included some extra money in your pledge for an add-on, you should send me a message NOW about what those add-ons were. Experience tells me that by the time all the money changes hands and I get around to sending out the surveys, most people have forgotten exactly what they'd planned on getting with that extra money. So if you send me a message now, I can make a note of it.

This Kickstarter has ended at $24,481! Just wanted to thank everyone for backing this project and helping this small press continue bringing quality SF&F themed anthologies into the world. The support this year and in all of our previous years has been tremendous. THANK YOU!
Right now, I'm exhausted. BUT I'm also excited to start working on getting these anthologies together for everyone. As you all know, the open call for submissions for these three anthologies is already started and will run until December 31, 2020. Here's the link to the submission guidelines for the writers out there:    . If you have a story idea that fits one of the three themes described below, write it up, revise it, polish it, and then send it in for consideration! You may end up in one of these anthologies! We've already got a ton of submissions and the editors have already started reading through them, looking for the best of the best to go along with the anchor author stories. (And some of the anchor author stories are already in as well.)

campaign.story:
What a topsy-turvy, bad-cliche-of-every-B-Movie-horror-trope year this has been. The type of year where we just had to hunker down and bury our heads in some projects because our yard didn't contain any sand. No shows, no author events, just a whole lot of time on our hands.
Well, we put that time to good use. Over the last six months, we focused on our backlog of projects and are ready for a few new ones. We are excited to bring you two more novels of amazing speculative fiction. Megan Mackie's The Devil's Day (book three in her Lucky Devil series—don't worry, we'll have a special pledge level for the series, for those who haven't read the first two), and Michelle D. Sonnier's tentatively titled An Unceasing Hunger, the long-anticipated sequel to The Clockwork Witch.
You can always find help at the Lucky Devil.
Rune Leveau—emerging Talent and one-time corporate prisoner—knew that better than anyone. She’d rebuilt her life at the Lucky Devil bar, with her Aunt Maddie’s help. Now, in her aunt’s memory, Rune continues that legacy.
But when it is time for the Devil to collect his due, Rune could lose it all…
With the days counting down until she must defend her claim to the House of Magdalene—including the bar—Rune and her partner, the cyber-spy St. Benedict, hunt for a way to defeat her challenger, the fire Talent, Abraxas. Instead, they uncover long-kept secrets. But do they hold the key?
No matter what, the Devil will have its Day…
An Unceasing Hunger
by Michelle D. Sonnier 
(Sequel to The Clockwork Witch)
Shunned by her family her entire life for not living up to their expectations—or prophesy—Arabella forges her own path and attains her greatest wish: to join the Sisterhood of Witches. Doing so in a manner no one ever anticipated.
As the first-ever technomancer, the way before her is fraught with peril. Can she survive the machinations of her order, or be ground between the gears of reluctant progress?
More important yet, can she succeed at her first assignment:  find the root cause of the famine sweeping through Ireland? A task that already claimed two witches of the Sortilege line.
Her future hangs in the balance... or her very life....
Dragons
by Ty Drago
For one young man and others of his kind, their very existence is a long-held secret. But someone knows. 
Someone not above kidnapping to learn about the secret society of dragons, though they wouldn't recognize the reality if he was walking beside them. 
To them, the answer is the end of the world. To Andy, it is staying alive. 
Ask yourself, are you Kind?

Megan Mackie is a writer, actor, and playwright. She started her writing career as an indie author and had such smashing success in her first year with her inaugural book The Finder of the Lucky Devil, that she made the transition to traditional publishing. She has become a personality at many cons, recognizable by her iconic leather hat and engaging smile. She has recently joined Bard’s Tower, a mobile con bookstore, and has sold her books next to great authors such as Peter David, Melinda Snodgrass, Dan Wells, Claudia Gray, John Jackson Miller, and Jim Butcher, to name a few.
She has written four novels including The Finder of the Lucky Devil, The Saint of Liars, Death and the Crone, and Saint Code: The Lost all of which will be re-releasing through eSpec Books. She is also a contributing writer in the role-playing game Legendlore soon to be published by Onyx Path Publishing.
Outside of writing, she likes to play games: board games, RPGs, and video games. She has a regular Pathfinder group who is working their way through Rapanthuk. She lives in Chicago with her husband and children, dog, three cats, and her mother in the apartment upstairs.
Michelle D. Sonnier writes dark urban fantasy, steampunk, and anything else that lets her combine the weird and the fantastic in unexpected ways. She even writes horror, although it took her a long time to admit that since she prefers the existential scare over blood and gore. She’s published short stories in a variety of print and online venues, and has upcoming projects with eSpec Books and Otter Libris. You can find her on Facebook (Michelle D. Sonnier, The Writer) or at www.michelledsonnier.com. She lives in Maryland with her husband, son, and a variable number of cats. The Clockwork Witch is her first full-length novel.

updates.update_content:
Hello! I hope everyone is well.
Just touching base to let you know that Devilish & Divine (previously Horns & Halos) is complete and typeset, except for the cover, which is in the queue. There is one cover wrapping up and then this one.
Also, An Unceasing Hunger has finished the first round of revisions and second round of edits. Just one more round of revisions and this one should be done, with the cover in the queue behind D&D.
Thank you for your patience, it shouldn't be much longer!

Hi, All!
No, I haven't forgotten about you. My apologies for the long silence, but there hasn't been much new to say. We still have two books in production--An Unceasing Hunger and Devilish & Divine (previously Horns & Halos)--but I am excited to say that we are wrapping up the text on D&D and need only work out the cover to go to press.

Hi everyone,
Just wanted to touch base on some updates. We have had to make a couple of last-minute changes.
First, Megan Mackie needed to withdraw from the collection Horns & Halos due to a personal conflict. To make up the slot/word count, we are adding three short-short stories by Christopher J. Burke, which combined come to roughly the same word count. The stories give a nice contrast to those already in the book, I think you will be pleased with the end result.

Hello, everyone.
Hope you are well and staying warm.
Just a note to let you know that Dragons has completed. Those due digital versions of the book have been sent the link. If you did not receive this, check the messages on your Kickstarter account. If you still did not receive it, please drop me a message.

Hello, everyone. 
Hope the new year is treating you right.
Just wanted to touch base with the progress we have made. As I type this, we are uploading the files for Lucky Devil Libations to the printer and shortly I will be creating the ebook for the digital stretch goal bonus.

Delighted to say I have the next ten days off, and we are making solid progress on all of the projects. We have preliminary sketches for the artwork for Dragons, we are doing final effects and touch-ups on the photographs for Lucky Devil Libations, and An Unceasing Hunger and Horns & Halos are wrapping up editing. 
Hope you had a wonderful holiday and have a happy and healthy New Year!

So a lot of conventions and events were hit hard this year by the need to go virtual, but most of them had time to plan for it. Not so for the conventions at the beginning of the year.
Ravencon had the shattering blow of not just losing all that projected income from their event, but they had to cancel it a mere few weeks before the actual event, which means they lost all of what they invested in that event, the projected income, and have the burden of storage fees and the like that continue throughout the year even if the event doesn't happen.

Hi everyone,
Hope you are doing well and have some room to breath after all the political excitement this week.
We are making strides in completing the books on this campaign and I just wanted to let you know where everything is.

David Sherman is the author or co-author of some three dozen books, most of which are about Marines in combat. He has written about US Marines in Vietnam (the Night Fighters series and three other novels), and the DemonTechseries about Marines in a fantasy world. The 18th Race trilogy is military science fiction.
Other than military, he wrote a non-conventional vampire novel, The Hunt, and a mystery, Dead Man's Chest. He has also released a collection of short fiction and non-fiction from early in his writing career, Sherman's Shorts; the Beginnings.
With Dan Cragg he wrote the popular Starfist series and its spin-off series, Starfist: Force Recon—all about Marines in the Twenty-fifth Century.; and a Star Wars novel, Jedi Trial. His books have been translated into Czech, Polish, German, and Japanese.
After going to war as a U.S. Marine infantryman, and spending decades writing about young men at war, he's burnt out on the subject and has finally come home. Today he's writing short fiction, mostly steampunk, and farcical fantastic Westerns.
He lives in sunny South Florida, where he doesn't have to worry about hypothermia or snow-shoveling-induced heart attacks. He invites readers to visit his website, novelier.com.
Keith R.A. DeCandido is a writer and editor of more than three decades' standing (though he usually does them sitting down). He is the author of more than 50 novels, more than 100 short stories, around 75 comic books, and more nonfiction than he is really willing to count. Included in those credits is fiction in the worlds of Star Trek, Alien, Farscape, Doctor Who, Andromeda, BattleTech, and many other science fiction milieus, as well as in universes of his own creation (such as the "Precinct" series of fantasy police procedurals, also published by the fine folks at eSpec).As an editor, he has worked with dozens of authors, among them Mike W. Barr, Alfred Bester, Margaret Wander Bonanno, Adam-Troy Castro, Peter David, Diane Duane, Harlan Ellison, Tony Isabella, Stan Lee, Tanith Lee, David Mack, David Michelinie, Andre Norton, Robert Silverberg, Dean Wesley Smith, S.P. Somtow, Harry Turtledove, Chelsea Quinn Yarbro, and Roger Zelazny. Having edited David Sherman's first two 18th Race books, Issue in Doubt and In All Directions, he is honored to assist him in finishing the trilogy by coauthoring To Hell and Regroup with him. Keith is also a martial artist (he got his third-degree black belt in karate in 2017), a musician (currently with the parody band Boogie Knights), and a baseball fan (having avidly followed the New York Yankees since 1976). Find out less about Keith as his cheerfully retro web site at DeCandido.net.
Christopher L. Bennett is a lifelong resident of Cincinnati, Ohio, with a B.S. in Physics and a B.A. in History from the University of Cincinnati. A fan of science and science fiction since age five, he has spent the past two decades selling original short fiction to magazines such as Analog Science Fiction and Fact (home of his "Hub" series of comedy adventures), BuzzyMag, and Galaxy's Edge. Since 2003, he has been one of Pocket Books' most prolific and popular authors of Star Trek tie-in fiction, including the epic Next Generation prequel The Buried Age, the Enterprise -- Rise of the Federation series, and the Original Series prequel The Captain's Oath. He has also written two Marvel Comics novels, X-Men: Watchers on the Walls and Spider-Man: Drowned in Thunder. His original novel Only Superhuman, perhaps the first hard science fiction superhero novel, was voted Library Journal's SF/Fantasy Debut of the Month for October 2012. He has three collections reprinting his original short fiction, Among the Wild Cybers: Tales Beyond the Superhuman from eSpec Books (containing an original Only Superhuman prequel novelette) and Hub Space: Tales from the Greater Galaxy and Crimes of the Hub from Mystique Press.

campaign.story:
Sometimes hope arrives as a little girl with a big heart.... 
.....and an even bigger chainsaw!

What is Marymae and the Nightmare Man?
Marymae is just like any little girl. She loves stories about brave princesses and spends a lot of time with her imaginary friend, Waldo. But one day her friend goes missing, and no one will believe her or take her growing concern seriously. Marymae can feel something is not right, and so decides she must go find him. But there’s something odd happening in the Forest of Make-Believe; those that were noble are now hiding away, inky shadows snake through the trees, and a growing darkness threatens to engulf even the bravest heart.
This illustrated novelette is filled with colorful characters, whimsical and crazy situations, and a powerful theme of having hope - even when surrounded by despair. Marymae has the sweetness and straightforwardness that only a child could have - which makes for many touching and hilarious moments as she finds herself gallivanting through the ever darkening Make-Believe Forest. Enjoy the journey with her as she discovers how to be a light to inspire courage in those around her, and how to love even the most broken heart.
It's a book that will uplift and inspire you with touching moments, while it makes you laugh at the absurdities of little girls and pirates wielding chainsaws!
Who will love Marymae and the Nightmare Man?
Anyone who enjoys a good story!
When writing Marymae, I wanted to capture that feeling of imagination and simplicity of childhood. Something that as adults we can get lost in, and enjoy the flow of the dramatic and the silly, to join the characters on their journey as they spring from one thing to the next. A refreshing light to illuminate the mundane every day.
Children and Parents!
Reading to your children has endless benefits:
It builds listening skills and imagination.
Reading comprehension.
Makes reading fun and something they’ll want to do.
A wonderful time to bound.
So many wonderful things! Even if your child can already read, don’t be afraid to read them books above their level. Good stories are meant to be shared, and there’s no age restriction on a good story!

What will the book look like?
The story runs about 11,500 words, will have a minimum of 10 illustrations, and be approximately 50 pages. It will be printed in 6x9, making it easy to store on your bookshelf.
One of the goals of this campaign is to provide the funding to commission more amazing art, which will increase the illustration and page count. See more details below.

updates.update_content: I am VERY excited to announce the book is done and to officially show off the cover!

Thank you all so so SO much! Because of everyone who contributed and shared, Marymae and the Nightmare Man has the support it needs to become a reality! 
With all the craziness in the world right now, I am very glad to share this happy news. It may just be one small story, but it's a story with a lot of heart and hope. And we all need hope in our lives, no matter if the world is going crazy, or if we've just had a bad day.

The Marymae Kickstarter is off to a great start! We're one week in, and at $1,839 pledged we're already 68% funded! We can't slow down now, lets conquer the funding and start working towards the stretch goals and more art!
I know so many people are excited for this project, so keep spreading the word and let others know about the awesome stuff we're doing to bring fun and hope-filled fiction into the world!

campaign.story:
Too often in fiction, I’ve found myself asking: Where are the moms?
Dead moms are a long-established trope, especially in sci-fi/fantasy. When you look at stories—and the way we talk about stories—there’s this sense that when a woman becomes a mother, she ceases to be the heroine. Instead, she’s relegated to a supporting role for her children, who are now meant to be the center of her life and the only reason for her existence. There are exceptions, as there are in everything, but overall, we’re left with the impression that once a woman becomes Mom, her tale ends. Mother figures also rarely figure into fiction the way father figures do. It’s not often that the wise or experienced elder sought out by a young protagonist is a woman.
Here’s the thing, though: A heroine doesn’t stop being a heroine because a kid came into her life.
So I'm putting together this anthology to turn the spotlight on bad ass moms. This is inspired in part, of course, by my own bad ass mom, who emigrated from China to the U.S. fresh out of school, got her PhD in statistics, and named me after her personal heroine and another bad ass mom, Marie Curie (Mary and Marie are the same name in Chinese).
Since moms and badassery come in infinite forms, I gave the contributing authors only one criterion: that their story be about a bad ass mother or mother figure. We’ve got moms across the age and experience spectrum, from grandmas to new moms. We've got warrior moms and moms who are bad ass in a quieter way. We’ve got biological moms, adoptive moms, and mom figures. A mom who runs a space colony, a hard-boiled detective mom, a witch mom, a coach who’s a mom figure to her students… and much, much more.
To bring these stories to life, I've partnered with the Crazy 8 Press crew: Russ Colchamiro, Peter David, Michael Jan Friedman, Robert Greenberger, Glenn Hauman, Paul Kupperberg, and Aaron Rosenberg. 
I've also assembled a fantastic line-up of additional authors (some of whom are bad ass moms themselves!): Danielle Ackley-McPhail, Derek Tyler Attico, T. Eric Bakutis,  Paige Daniels, Kathleen O'Shea David, Heather E. Hutsell, Kris Katzen, Karissa Laurel, Khaalidah Muhammad-Ali, TJ Perkins, Jenifer Purcell Rosenberg, Joanna Schnurman, Hildy Silverman, and Denise Sutton.
And who am I? Hi, I'm Mary Fan, author of sci-fi/fantasy books about intrepid heroines, including Stronger Than a Bronze Dragon, Artificial Absolutes, and Starswept. Publishers Weekly, School Library Journal, Booklist, and Kirkus liked my books, so I guess I get to call myself "critically acclaimed." I'm also the co-editor of the Brave New Girls anthology series about girls in STEM.
Our awesome cover art is the work of Sean "MunkyWrench" Eddingfield (background art) and Streetlight Graphics (design and layout).

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
90% of the stories for this anthology are not only complete, but edited as well. And of course, you've already seen our awesome cover art. All that's left to do is wrap up those last few stories and format the manuscript. As the co-editor of the illustrated Brave New Girls anthology series, I'm more than familiar with wrangling talent. My back-up plans have back-up plans.

I'm also very familiar with marketing and giveaways. Brave New Girls was the product of a crowd-funding campaign (meant for a single anthology, but we out-raised our goal and found a publishing model that meant we could publish several more). I've run several giveaway campaigns to promote my own books, and I've always delivered rewards as promised.

Of course, no one can 100% predict the future. But barring a catastrophe of apocalyptic proportions, this anthology is happening.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_userinfo: Final book files are in the house!
updates.update_content:
Hey everyone! Thank you again for all your support! Just wanted to give a quick update on where we are with the anthology. I got the final book files for both the paperback and e-book versions of the anthology earlier this week, and they're now in the process of publishing onto various online platforms (Amazon, Barnes & Noble, iBooks, etc.). The official release date is this Saturday, July 11.
Digital rewards will be start going out in late July/early August. Paperback rewards may take a bit longer since printing schedules have been thrown off by the whole coronavirus situation, but I should be able to get them all in the mail by late August/early September.

updates.update_userinfo: Quick update about BAD ASS MOMS
updates.update_content:
Hey everyone! Hope you're all staying safe and well during these strange, strange times! I just wanted to give you a quick update about the anthology. The manuscript just went to formatting, and we're on track for a July release. Rewards will start being delivered shortly after that.

updates.update_userinfo: We made our first stretch goal!!
updates.update_content:
WE MADE OUR FIRST STRETCH GOAL! I’m so excited to announce that we will be adding a story from Keith RA DeCandido! Thank you so much for your support!!
We’ve still got a few days left... let’s see how many more we can unlock... :-D

updates.update_userinfo: WE DID IT!! Now, let's go beyond... :-D
updates.update_content:
Holy wow, y'all!! We just hit our target! Thank you so much to everyone who's backed this project and helped us spread the word!!!
We still have 5 days left in the campaign, and I just know we can hit some of those stretch goals! A bonus story by Keith R.A. DeCandido! Hardcovers! Illustrations! I mean, how cool would those be? :-D

Y'ALL. We are SO FLAMIN' CLOSE! I really think we're going to make it!
And I'm going to be extra optimistic and say I think we're even going to unlock that first stretch goal: an additional story by geek god Keith R.A. DeCandido! Keith, who's written dozens of bestselling original and tie-in books (including for Star Trek, Marvel, Supernatural, and Doctor Who), pitched an incredible story about a supernatural hunter for hire who lives in the Bronx with her three kids. Also, I should mention that he has generously agreed to include 2 Tuckerizations, which means you could be a character in it!

7 days left, and we are SO CLOSE!! Less than $500 to go... fingers crossed that we’ll cross the finish line soon! I’m still hoping for those stretch goals :-)
Today, I'm spotlighting BAD ASS MOMS author Heather E. Hutsell, a prolific writer who has published over a dozen books. Heather's story, "Shape Up or Ship Out," is about an artificial intelligence who nurtures delinquent boys sent into her care.

We crossed the $4,000 threshold!!! We're so close to our goal now! Thank you so much to everyone who's supported us! We have one week left to the campaign, and I think we can unlock at least some of those stretch goals... Please help us out and share :-)
Up today in the BAD ASS MOMS author spotlight: Hildy Silverman, who's published several pieces of short fiction and is the former editor-in-chief of Space and Time Magazine. Hildy's story, "Raising the Dead," is about a human mom on the PTA of a school for supernatural kids.

Today's BAD ASS MOMS author spotlight is on Glenn Hauman, author of numerous pieces original and tie-in fiction. He's also my fellow Crazy 8 Press author... and was fictitiously killed by 20 authors in Crazy 8 Press's 2018 anthology They Keep Killing Glenn (including me... I "killed" him by dropping a stack of books on him). Glenn's story, "The Devil You Know: A Scoubidou Mystery," is about a mom who... may have done something not-so-legal in her past. Won't give away more because, well, spoilers.

10 days to go, and we're almost 90% of the way there! Thank you thank you to everyone who's supported us!!! I just know we can make it... and maybe even unlock some of those stretch goals! I mean, how cool would it be to get illustrations??
Today, I'm spotlighting BAD ASS MOMS author TJ Perkins, who has published multiple books for all age groups. TJ's story for the anthology, "Perfect Insanity," is about a witch mom who battles dark magic while wrangling her kids.

campaign.story:
Welcome to the Age of Empyre Kickstarter! This marks my 17th published novel and my 7th crowdfunding campaign. I'm thrilled that two books in the series have made the New York Times Bestsellers list, three of the books became USA Today bestsellers, and three have made it onto the Washington Post Hardcover bestseller list on multiple occasions. This campaign has become the third most-backed and fourth most-funded fiction Kickstarter of all time.
Well, we are down to our last one hour of the Kickstarter, and Robin and I wanted to say . . .
to all backers old and new.  Your support of our work is truly amazing and we appreciate the faith you have put into the series and us in making this our best Kickstarter yet.  
And for anyone who might have missed this Kickstarter, we have your back!  You'll be able to join the fun through the manual add process of Kickstarter. Just use this link and we'll get you added.
And keep your eyes open for updates from Kickstarter and emails from BackerKit as we start rolling out the rewards!  We'll keep you in the loop!
What is the book about? Here's the marketing copy from the back cover:
A DOOR OPENS. AN ARMY OF DRAGONS ADVANCE. AND THE FATE OF THE LIVING RESTS WITH THE DEAD.
After obtaining the secret to creating dragons, the leader of the Fhrey has turned the tide of war once more--but gaining the advantage has come at a terrible price. While Imaly plots to overthrow the fane for transgressions against his people, a mystic and a keeper are the only hope for the Rhunes. Time is short, and the future of both races hangs in the balance. In this exciting conclusion to the Legends of the First Empire series, the Great War finally comes to a climactic end, and with it dawns a new era in the Age of Empyre.
For returning readers, recaps are available so you can be reminded about what has happened so far. 
Want to check out my writing style? Well, it's a bit tricky because this book opens in the middle of the story, and I didn't want to expose people to spoilers. So to help mitigate that, I took the sample chapter and redacted the names by doing substitutions. I should note that this sample hasn't yet gone through copyediting, but it should be in relatively good shape.  Another spoiler-free option would be to read from the start of the series, so I included a sample chapter to Age of Myth (the first book of the series) as well.
Age of Myth Sample Chapter
Age of Empyre redacted Sample Chapter
This project mirrors my other Kickstarters, but for new people, I'm summarizing some important aspects of what you'll receive.
All physical books come signed: a perk for ordering the books directly from me.
All ebooks are DRM-free, which means you can load them on any device: computer, smartphone, and tablet without any locking feature preventing you from moving it from place to place.
For backing this project, your name will be printed in the Acknowledgment Section so everyone will know that you are an awesome supporter of the project (you can, of course, opt-out if you choose)
The official release through the retail channels is May 5, 2020, but all levels with ebooks will receive the story in March.
For the levels that provide a physical book, we've bundled the ebook to ensure early access to the story. If you don't want to pay for the ebook (for instance you only want a physical copy), there will be a process for you to pre-order just the hardcover after the Kickstarter is over.
Anyone receiving the physical book will also receive a matching signed bookmark. If you choose a reward level with multiple books, each of them will also have a matching bookmark.
If you are missing one or more of the previous ebooks, you can purchase some of them here (use DIGITAL DOUBLE TROUBLE, DIGITAL THREE BOOK NIGHT, or the "add-on" feature) to get copies of Age of Legend, Age of Death, or extra copies of Age of Empyre for a friend. Unfortunately, we can't make the other ebooks available (Age of Myth, Age of Swords, and Age of War) because the rights are owned by Penguin Random House, and only they can sell copies of those titles. So, you'll have to buy books #1 through #3 from your favorite ebook retailer.
If you are missing one or more of the prior hardcovers, this Kickstarter is the best way to get them. Not only will they be signed, but they are sold at a discount ($25 rather than $27 or $28). Also, we have significantly discounted the shipping costs for people located outside the US, and future purchases won't have the "bulk shipping" advantage that a Kickstarter provides.
The Legends of the First Empire series is a six-book epic fantasy, and the first three books have been released by Del Rey (a fantasy imprint of Penguin Random House) from 2016 - 2018. The remaining three titles have been self-published and released on an accelerated schedule (3 books in a 10-month span: Age of Legend - Jul 2019 | Age of Death - Feb 2020 | Age of Empyre - May 2020).  
Like my best-selling Riyria novels, these books are also set in the fictional world of Elan, but the events occur 3,000 years in the past. It IS NOT necessary to know anything about the other stories, but for those who do read both, you'll learn the truth about a number of lies regarding various historical figures. 
At the time of this Kickstarter launch, Age of Death hasn't officially "hit the street," but here is some data regarding how readers have rated the books in the series on Amazon, Goodreads, and Audible.com.  I'm proud that only 2.2% have had poor ratings (1- and 2-star) and the vast majority (nearly 90%) have garnered 4- and 5-stars.
In case you are not familiar with the other books in the series, here is a bit about each.
Age of Myth:  Since time immemorial, humans have worshipped the gods they call Fhrey, truly a race apart: invincible in battle, masters of magic, and seemingly immortal. But when a god falls to a human blade, the balance of power between men and those they thought were gods changes forever. Now, only a few stand between humankind and annihilation: Raithe, reluctant to embrace his destiny as the God Killer, Suri, a young seer burdened by signs of impending doom, and Persephone, who must overcome personal tragedy to lead her people. The Age of Myth is over; the time of rebellion has begun.
Age of Swords:  Raithe, the God Killer, may have started the rebellion by killing a Fhrey, but long-standing enmities dividing the Rhune make it all but impossible to unite against a common foe. And even if the clans can join forces, how will they defeat an enemy whose magical prowess makes the Fhrey indistinguishable from gods? The answer lies in a faraway land populated by a reclusive and dour race. With time running out, Persephone leads a small band of misfits in a desperate search for aid, a quest that will take them into the darkest depths of Elan. There, an ancient adversary waits—an enemy as surprising as it is deadly.
Age of War:  The alliance of humans and renegade Fhrey is fragile—and about to be tested as never before. Persephone keeps the human clans from turning on one another through her iron will and a compassionate heart while Nyphron, seeks to advance his own nefarious agenda. Old loyalties will be challenged while fresh conspiracies will threaten to undo all that Persephone has accomplished. In the darkest hour, when hope is all but lost, new heroes will rise . . . but at what terrible cost?
Age of Legend: After years of warfare, humanity has gained the upper hand and has pushed the Fhrey to the edge of their homeland—but no farther. Now comes the pivotal moment. Persephone’s plan to use the stalemate to seek peace is destroyed by an unexpected betrayal that threatens to hand victory to the Fhrey and leaves a dear friend in peril. Humanity’s only hope lies in the legend of a witch, a forgotten song, and a simple garden door.
Age of Death: Winter blankets the land, and more than hope has died. Barred by the tower of Avempartha, the western army cannot invade the Fhrey homeland. So it must seek a way across the Nidwalden River before the fane obtains the secret of dragons. As time runs out for both humanity and the mystic Suri, the only chance for the living rests with the dead. Having made their fateful choice, can a handful of misfits do the impossible, or are they forever lost to an inescapable grave? As in Virgil's Aeneid, Dante's Divine Comedy, and Milton's Paradise Lost, the most epic tales transcend the world of the living. It's time to see what lies in Elan's Age of Death. 
Okay, so we've learned a bit about the book and the series, but what about me? Well, my name is Michael J. Sullivan, and I’m a full-time novelist. To type those words is kind of surreal, as writing isn't a career that most can make a living at. I'm eternally grateful to all my readers who make it feasible to live a dream I never thought would be possible.
Like many (too many), my road to authorship wasn't an easy one. I wrote in a variety of genres from 1979 to 1994, and after thirteen novels and more than a hundred rejections, I quit after vowing never to write creatively again. Well, never turned out to be a bit more than a decade, as I couldn't suppress the itch to write any longer. Over those years, a story had been growing in my head, and I decided to write it but with a condition: I wouldn't seek publication. I hoped that a few friends and my dyslexic daughter (who had always struggled with reading) would take a look, and that would be good enough for me.
After reading the books, my wife made it her mission to make sure they saw the light of day. She willed them into existence, first with a small-press (who was well-intentioned but ultimately provided us no income nor any substantial readership), later through self-publishing (which worked much better), and eventually, she attracted the interest of Orbit (the fantasy imprint of a big-five publisher, Hachette Book Group). The rest, as they say, is history.
In the publishing business, I'm what's referred to as a "hybrid" because I've released books through traditional publishers as well as utilizing self-publishing.  If you want to learn why I do that, you can look at the Why Self-Publish section below.
All told, I've written 32 novels: 13 are sitting in a trunk never to see the light of day, 12 are released by a traditional publisher, 11 are currently or previously self-published,  1 is releasing soon, and 2 more are written (these are books in my next series, The Rise and the Fall). 
Some of my publishing accomplishments include:
New York Times Bestselling Author (twice)
USA Today Bestselling Author (3 times)
3 books with multiple appearances on the Washington Post Hardcover Bestseller list
2M+ English language books sold
90+ foreign language contracts in 14 languages
2,200+ days (6.0+ years) on the Amazon Top 100 Fantasy Author list
8-time Goodreads Choice Award Nominee
4 Earphone Award Wins and one Audie Award Nomination
One of the Top 50 most-followed authors on Goodreads
Named by io9 as one of the most successful self-published science fiction and fantasy authors
Named to more than 260 best-of or most-anticipated lists including those compiled by Library Journal, Amazon, Barnes and Noble, Audible, and Goodreads.  
This handy chart provides a quick and easy way to determine what you receive at the various reward levels.  
As you can see, we offer a wide range of pledge levels from the low-level $5 to the comprehensive "All In" ($25 per book + $10 for ebook) which provides all six novels of the series as well as early access to the story via the ebook. For the multi-book levels, you'll be able to select which titles you desire for each book and you can even use it to buy multiple copies of the Age of Empyre book.
Because we will be using BackerKit to fulfill the project, this allows backers to customize their pledge to get exactly the items they are interested in. To receive these "Add-ons" you should do the following:
Select the reward level that covers the largest number of items you want to receive.
Select the "Add-ons" from the table below and note the cost of each.
Increase your pledge amount to include your pledge level plus the costs of the desired add-ons.
When the Kickstarter is over you'll be able to "distribute" that excess money to the various desired add-ons.
Below is the list of add-ons available:

In addition, we'll also continue Robin's Tip Jar (as it was missed in recent Kickstarters, and people appreciated its return in the last Kickstarter. Some notes about a few of the add-ons.
Montemorcey Bag - for the last Kickstarter, we offered this in black but the supplier has had problems keeping that color in stock. So, this time around we switched to a "natural" color with green handles (which we have never seen go out of stock). All other aspects of the bag will be the same. The size is 12" x 13" x 5".
Sullifan Bag - One of the stretch goals was an alternate bag design and we decided to make a heraldic crest for "Sullifans" The design is a work in progress, but I wanted to show you the direction we are going. This crest features items from both series (the Tower of Avempartha and a Gilarabrwn.  We suspect that many of the backers of this Kickstarter also backed the last one (and as such you already have a set of 5 bookmarks). But if you missed getting the "5-set bookmarks" you can order a complete set separately. NOTE: Only the Age of Empyre bookmark will be signed.
Here are some examples to help you figure out how to calculate various orders with "Add-ons" included.

We have no desire to make a profit shipping the books, so we have priced our shipping fees at cost. That said, all the fees do add up. Here are some of the things the shipping costs cover: postage, insurance, packing material, fulfillment company picking and packing fees, and shipping the books to the fulfillment company.  Shipping is automatically added to your pledge and is based on your country. We've deeply discounted foreign postage rates so that the shipping for a single book is $7 - $9 regardless of your location.
US: $7 - $14
Canada: $8 - $15
Most foreign countries: $9 - $16
Note: Some foreign countries have higher shipping, but we have applied discounts to keep this expensive as low as possible. 
Normally when buying directly from us, we ship via the USPS, and this is very expensive. But doing a Kickstarter allows us to consolidate a number of orders, send one large shipment, and utilize fulfillment partners in various overseas markets (like Canada and Europe). Shipping locally means that backers will not have to pay VAT, customs, or import fees (we'll absorb those costs), and it also helps to keep the overseas shipping costs down. Even with all those efforts, postage can drive up the cost to non-us backers, so we're taking some of our profits and using it to drive down the shipping costs further. She's edited books by David Gemmel, Naomi Novik, a number of the books in the Star Wars franchise, two New York Times Bestsellers from Steve Berry, and eight of my novels.

 Shawn Speakman (publisher/distributor) - Shawn started up Grim Oak Press to help pay medical bills after beating cancer a second time. Generally, he's produced anthologies and premium hardcovers, and Age of Empyre will be the third time he's releasing a trade publication. Some of the authors Shawn has worked with include: Terry Brooks, Brandon Sanderson, Raymond E. Feist, Pierce Brown, Naomi Novik, Jacquelin Carey, Jim Butcher, Stephen R. Donaldson, Mark Lawrence, Janny Wurtz, Peter Orullian, and Barbara Hambly.

They've been shipping books ordered from our website for more than a year, and they expertly handled the shipping for our last Kickstarter Age of Legend. I've found them to be professional, conscientious, and hardworking. They've shipped more than 9,500 books for us and they make running a Kickstarter so much easier than when we used to do all the shipping ourselves.
As I mentioned, this will be my 7th crowdfunding campaign, and I'm proud to say they have all been a huge success. In fact, several of them rank on the top of the charts both in the number of backers and the funds raised.
